11:10 am

(@GBKrona: GSK's down 0.3%. Surely that's barely a rounding error in the scheme of things.)

BE11:10am

Key Them e: Alum inium – upside risk: There are three Chinese policy proposals that if implemented could dramatically change
the fundamentals of the aluminium market (Metals & Mining : Aluminium equities: Upside risk apparent ). At present we see the market in surplus but this is driven by China overproducing and exporting its excess to the rest of the world which is in significant
deficit of the metal (1Mt+). The proposals are 1. Beijing Winter Production Cuts (1.2Mt potential im pact): 30% of production
around Beijing and Tianjin is proposed to be cut during winter (Nov-March). 2. Sm elter Rectification (2Mt): Elimination of non-
compliant post May-2013 built smelters across the country that did not receive full Govt approvals (relating to power efficiency and environmental standards). Key dates are reporting by 30-June, investigated by 15-Sept and shut by 15-Oct for smelters that remain noncompliant. 3. No overall capacity growth (m eeting growing dem and). Also proposed is that all new capacity that meets approvals must replace existing capacity. In an industry where demand growth is steady (~5%/yr), zero new capacity could cause a severe shortage. These cuts could push the market into a deficit and have a significant impact on the Aluminium price with Norsk Hydro, Rio Tinto and S32 exposed.

11:12 am
PM11:12am

To most people, the authority with which an investor speaks out on the policies of a company is proportionate to how many shares they own.

A 4.1 per cent “stake” in BHP Billiton would give activist Elliott Associates every right to push for changes at the miner, which on Friday approved $250m in relief for an environmental disaster in Brazil.

But a “stake” — in the sense of a full shareholding — is precisely what the New York-based hedge fund does not possess. It is time for shareholders and media to understand the practices of activists better, lest they overestimate the financial commitments they have made to their targets.

Activists often lobby for sensible reforms that other investors may support. Their rise outside the US counterpoises the waning power of so-called “long” pensions and insurance investors.

Elliott’s tilt against BHP reflects their growing confidence. In April, news organisations reported that the hedge fund had taken a stake in BHP and was pressing for a spin-off of the oil and gas division.

Elliott itself only claimed to have “a long economic interest in respect of 4.1 per cent” of the London-listed shares. This does not mean it had spent £1.1bn on shares, as a pension fund might. It is more likely that the fund did a deal with a big bank involving derivatives called “contracts for difference”.

Elliott would make money when BHP shares rose and lose money when they fell. But its outlay would be limited to a percentage of the cost of purchasing real stock. Bankers say it could be as low as 5 per cent or as high as 30 per cent.

The fund, which declined to comment, would pay no stamp tax, have no direct voting rights, be entitled to no direct dividends and have no obligation to participate in rights issues. Moreover, exposure gained through CFDs cannot be independently verified.

Shareholders should be aware that activists may have invested by quite different means. Their objectives may be equally divergent.

You'll remember this has been a part of the bear case with regards Plus. The need to join the "sign-up bonus" arms race to keep snaring new punters and keep feeding the machine.

11:19 am

BE11:19am

Here's Berenberg, who have.

BE11:20am

Most notably, EBITDA margins are expected to be considerably higher than forecast due to lower customer acquisition costs. There is, however, significant regulatory pressure still on the horizon. With that in mind, while we increase our estimates by close to 30% at an EPS level for 2017E, we only raise our 2018/19E estimates by 10%. As such, we move our price target from 450p to 560p, but remain Holders.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Historically, Plus500 has marketed aggressively, particularly in regards to how much it would “pay per click” for online advertising but also via the use of incentives. Plus500 has seemingly taken a different approach and reduced this spend. Given the progress that it has made ytd, we reduce our average user acquisition cost (AUAC) by $100 from our previous estimate of $1,050. With slight changes to the other cost line items also, we have increased our EBITDA margins from 46% to c54% for 2017E.

BE11:21am

On 29 June, the FCA announced that it will delay implementing changes to conduct rules for firms selling CFDs to retail clients pending the outcome of ESMA discussions. Due to the delay, Plus500’s performance over the next few months is likely to be better than it would otherwise have been. However, the measures ESMA is considering are broadly similar to those proposed by the FCA. The long-term effect is thus unlikely to change, although it is very difficult to forecast what the exact impact will be. Given this uncertainty, we remain cautious.

PM11:22am

Here's the ESMA note on product intervention..

BE11:23am

It is worth noting the EBITDA for Q1’17 was $45.8m (margin 59%), representing 42% of our full year forecast of $109.5m. With new EU regulation (post ESMA and FCA comments last week) unlikely to be enacted until H1’18, there is clearly considerable upside risk to CY17 forecasts and probably CY18 forecasts. We shall review our assumptions and update accordingly. Despite the clear regulatory risk, the stock remains a BUY, trading on a pre-updated CY17 PE of 9.5x, rising to 10.8x in CY18 and yielding 6.3% falling to 5.6%

We think another profit warning for Home Credit is likely, since guidance remains too optimistic, in our view. The disruption to date validates our previously held concerns about rising impairments and customer attrition. We see risk to impairments in Vanquis and Moneybarn and highlight pressures on the consumer, regulatory intrusion and the risk to 2018 DPS. We reflect these concerns in our valuation. The downside to our 2000p TP is 17.8%. Reiterate SELL.

BE11:27am

BE11:27am

11:28 am
PM11:28am

I've fallen off the Numis distribution list -- but do they have abroader piece out on Speciality lenders?

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:28am

Everything from Close Brothers to Metro Bank

11:28 am
BE11:29am

I'll have a look in a minute. Numis's James Hamilton is very good on the sub-prime stuff, thought not always directionally correct.

BE11:29am

Anyay, back to Liberum. They've done some estimates on the average Provident customer and concluded that about two-thirds of their post-tax income goes on rent, credit card payments an a car loan.

BE11:29am

It looks like this.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

BE11:29am

I'd speculate that the "gross salary on rent" figure looks a little low, given people renting while earning £17k will tend to be in service industries which demands living somewhere urban where rents tend to be higher ...

BE11:29am

For example, you can do a quick cross check of the map showing rents are highest in London and Manchester ... https://homelet.co...index/regional-map

11:29 am
BE11:30am

.... With the debt map showing those seeking advice are disproportionately in places like London and Manchester. http://www.thisism...y-seek-advice.html

BE11:30am

Liberum's working does touch on this tho. Let me share some more.

BE11:30am

51% of Moneybarn customers have income in the £12.5k to £22.5k income range. The weighted average income for this 51% is £17,381. We believe the £25k average income quoted in the 2015 annual report for Moneybarn customers is skewed upwards by small numbers of customer with much higher income of up to £100k.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Since Provident notes that a greater proportion of Vanquis customers live in rented accommodation, we assume the same is true of the Moneybarn customer base. Our estimate of monthly rental expenditure is based on the average percentage of gross salary spent on rent, as estimated by the HomeLet Rental Index. We note that our forecast of £419 is significantly below the national average monthly rental payment recorded by HomeLet of £901 for May, although this is skewed upwards by the South East and Greater London.

BE11:31am

We also assume that a typical Moneybarn customer will also have a Vanquis credit card.
Our conclusions are that as a percentage of after tax monthly salary for the majority of Moneybarn customers, 33% is spent on rent, 23% on car loan repayments and 10% on credit card repayments - a total of 66%.

BE11:31am

So ..... real terms wage deflation is probably not great news.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

"limited flexibility in Moneybarn customer incomes to absorb pressure from a vhigher real cost of living" is how they put it.

BE11:32am

There's also the regulatory angle, with regards backloading interest rates and etc, which we've covered many times in the past. Liberum concludes that it's not in the price.

BE11:32am

We now value PFG at 11x 2018 EPS,
which is still a c.20% premium to the
specialist lenders (ex. BUR LN). We
believe the multiple is appropriate to
capture the downside risks.

11:32 am
PM11:33am

This feels like a bit and persistent theme all of a sudden, Bryce

PM11:33am

Seemingly consumer credit has been growing at five times growth in household income

BE11:34am

Yep. In terms of the Numis sector wrap, I'll hoof that up as well since it's on theme.

11:34 am
PM11:34am

If that stat is correct, we are looking at tin hat time, for some

BE11:34am

We believe the cycle is turning; asset yields have fallen, banks have been relaxing their credit standards, and consumer credit is growing at c.5x household income growth. Impairment is at an all-time low, and the household savings rate is down to just 2.6% – it all sounds to us very much like the top of a cycle. Furthermore, the loan book growth at Close Brothers has slowed dramatically. Ahead of the Credit Crisis, all the long-duration, low-margin lenders, which were growing rapidly, came to a very bad end. Paragon and Northern Rock had growth rates of c.30%, while Close lost market share in the four years prior to the crisis. With its first-half 2017 results, Paragon reported 20.4% front book loan growth against the 4.1% loan book growth reported in the first nine months of this year for Close. The macro picture had started to deteriorate prior to the election which, we believe, will increase uncertainty, reducing investment and spending further. Excluding food, retail sales fell in the year to May, real incomes are declining, and the key service sector PMI declined to 53.8 from 55.8 last month. The June GfK consumer confidence survey showed confidence falling to negative 10 from negative 5 in May. The Lloyds Bank business survey conducted after the election showed the balance of firms being confident in their prospects fell to 21% from 40% prior to the election. The houseprice:income ratio is 8% ahead of its peak prior to the crisis and the CML has downgraded its BTL (the marginal buyer) forecasts.

BE11:34am

We have assumed that the UK enters a recession in 2018 and
that impairment returns will be half way between where our previous 2018 forecasts were and the worst point of the credit crisis for all assets apart from mortgages. Given the credit crisis was very kind to mortgage assets, we have assumed that impairment returns to its credit crisis peak. As the following table shows, we have downgraded our forecasts and target prices for the sub-sector. Despite the substantial downgrades, the sector does not look very expensive. Nevertheless, we are cautious as we believe the market will probably over-estimate the likely eventual downgrades that will be required once downgrades start manifesting themselves.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

That is indeed James Hamilton, and has done 27 pages on the theme. Contact your Numis salesperson for the full thing.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

So anyway, in terms of corporate there's Supergroup.

SuperGroup PLC (SGP:LSE): Last: 1,528, up 33 (+2.21%), High: 1,602, Low: 1,480, Volume: 180.14k
BE11:39am

Warned for a second time about someone getting their bag nicked with a copy of their results in them.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

They warned last week and put out skeleton results, but it seems no one really noticed so they're now repeated the warning on a slow news day and that's done the trick. Blanket coverage.

PM11:40am

hehehe

BE11:40am

The numbers were fine. As were last week's skeleton numbers, though I think 2018 guidance looked a bit odd.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Want Canaccord to chew through the detail? It'd save us having to.

BE11:41am

With headline results having been pre-released last Thursday, there are no surprises in the numbers or guidance today in the full preliminary results release. The key message for us is that the company's strong growth is disciplined and well-planned across channels and geographies as well as being under-pinned by infrastructure investment and product innovation. The brand is in excellent health, and we are now in a phase where we expect recent investment to start to be leveraged.

BE11:42am

In summary, sales +27.4% to £752m (+12.7% LFL inc. online). Gross margin down 130bps (of which c. 100bps is channel mix). Operating margin -70bps to 11.9% reflecting investment in the business (inc. £2.1m of one-off set-up costs for new warehouses). North America has reached break-even, as expected, while losses in China were £2.2m, as expected. Underlying PBT of £87.0m was slightly ahead of our £86.5m. DPS increased by 20.7% to 28.0p, slightly ahead of our 27.0p. The company expects FY18E PBT to be in line with market expectations of c. £98m - CGe £97.0m (94.3p). Within this, the gross margin is expected to be broadly flat on an underlying trading basis (sourcing efficiencies offset input cost pressure), but an accelerated inventory 're-base' is expected to dilute the margin on a one-off basis by c. 100bps. This will be offset by associated cost efficiencies that will be recurring. Importantly, the company is now in a phase where "during the next two years we anticipate that we will leverage our investments as we continue to grow our revenues and deliver improvements to our Design to Customer process".

11:42 am
BE11:43am

The bed-rock of SuperGroup's continued growth is product innovation, be it the increasing participation of womenswear (now 36.5% of the mix) or expansion into newer areas such as Superdry Sport. In the UK, this is augmented by two new format trial stores which are seeing double-digit LFL sales growth. Ten stores will be re-furbished using learnings from the trial in FY18E.
Online sales grew by 35% in FY17 and now represent 25.9% of Retail sales. There is still more to go for here, with regional fulfilment capability in the pipeline. 125k of new owned space (on a base of 1m sq ft) will be added in FY18E, of which 75k is Europe and 50k USA. In the US, importantly, the company is taking advantage of the tough environment to negotiate good rents in prime areas. Importantly, a very disciplined approach is being taken towards space in department stores. While Wholesale saw very strong sales growth of 43% in FY17, management remains confident that it can continue
to drive double-digit (mid teens) growth into the medium term.
All of this leaves us very comfortable with SuperGroup as one of our top picks in the sector. The shares trade on a calendar 2017E PE of 16.5x, falling to 14.7x in cal. 18E. Our DCF-based target price of 2012p implies a terminal EBIT margin of 12.5% (so modest leverage from the current level) and a terminal EV/EBIT of 12x (vs. 12.4x cal. 17E). Maintain BUY.

BE11:43am

Couple of caveats to throw in there. One is on online sales .......

BE11:44am

Yeah, they're growing quick. But isn't that in part because of Superdry trying to cut down its reliance on ebay?

11:44 am
BE11:45am

As in, it dumps loads of stuff through the Superdry Store. http://stores.ebay...The-Superdry-Store

BE11:45am

How much is "online growth" simply a cannibalisation of that, reflecting the change of discount channel strategy a year or so ago?

PM11:46am

Fair question

11:46 am
BE11:46am

(@Lefevre: by memory, management had a no-discounting policy so used ebay as an arms-length way to get rid of end-of-season excess tat.)

PM11:46am

Did you read the statement on these two non-execs going?

http://www.investe...1707030700058426J/

PM11:47am

11:47 am

But i might be wrong

PM11:48am

Just feels a bit off

BE11:48am

Hm. The other bit of the numbers that was worth highlighting, I thought, was the growth of wholesale vs retail.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

As in, Supergroup seems to be slowing its own store openings and relying more on department stores and whatnot.

BE11:50am

Which seems a tad risky to me, given what we know of how the high street is trading, and is the opposite strategy to most brands in the luxury or affordable luxury bracket (which can't really be compared with a Chelmsford t-shirt shop that specialises in bunk hiragana, but whatever).

11:53 am

PM11:54am

(Flaneur -- calm, calm...)

11:54 am
BE11:54am

This one's from Bernstein.

BE11:54am

PR19 timetable: Despite having just completed the reporting of the second fiscal year of the current regulatory period (AMP 6), the next regulatory period is beginning to come into focus. The first event will be the publication of Ofwat's consultation methodology on July 11th, followed by a final methodology and risk based review in December 2017 (which will include a provisional WACC determination).

BE11:54am

Expected WACC reduction: We have conducted an extensive analysis on the key components comprising the PR19 WACC and have compiled a bottom-up estimate of the potential outcome in December. In a best case scenario have derived a CPI/RPI weighted real WACC of 3.6%, with a worst case of 2.8%. Note that this is not directly comparable to the current real WACC (3.6%), which is 100% RPI-based. On a like for like basis, we see a 60-130bps reduction in the WACC.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Company impact in our worst case WACC scenario
-Dividends: A WACC of 2.8% and a payout ratio at the upper end of the "sustainable" range (1.1x dividend cover/~91% payout ratio) implies a 4% dividend cut for both companies. In Exhibit 8 and Exhibit 9 we have presented our estimate of the impact under more severe WACC assumptions (and a lower payout ratio) for UU and SVT respectively.

BE11:55am

Exhibit 8's much too complicated to post here. Have Exhibits 9 and 10 instead.

BE11:55am

11:55 am
BE11:55am

PM11:55am

I want to see Exhibit 8 now

BE11:55am

Seriously, you don't. I couldn't zoom the PDF sufficiently to make any sense of it, and that was on a proper sized screen.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

I'm not going to bring you Exhibits 15 and 16 either, which makes this next paragraph of limited use.

BE11:56am

Recap of current RCV premia – supporting our rating changes: In Exhibit 15 and Exhibit 16 we show the premium to RCV for Severn Trent and United Utilities over a period of 10+ years. This assessment underpins our rating changes, with Severn Trent currently trading significantly ahead of its long-term average (33% vs. 18%) and UU trading in line (at 15%). We do not believe the market is adequately pricing in the risk of a material reduction in the WACC for PR19 and the heightened political risk, which makes M&A unlikely.

BE11:57am

So, Severn downgraded to underperform. UUs to neutral.

11:57 am
Severn Trent PLC (SVT:LSE): Last: 2,164, down 18 (-0.82%), High: 2,164, Low: 2,133, Volume: 442.04k
United Utilities Group PLC (UU.:LSE): Last: 861.50, down 6 (-0.69%), High: 861.87, Low: 849.00, Volume: 1.85m
BE11:57am

We believe M&A is less likely until 2020 - we have therefore removed the M&A premium from our valuation, leaving it 100% DCF-based. We also revised down our RAV premium-based terminal value to 1.1x closing RCV, from 1.2x, due to lower RCV growth from the move to CPI and a lower allowed cost of capital.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

As I say, an echo of the MOST note from last week. https://www.ft.com...-b553-e2df1b0c3220

BE11:59am

Though we never have a lot of fun when having to write about WACC and RCV for the paper.

undefined
11:58 am
PM11:59am

Bank of England facing a strike

PM11:59am

https://www.ft.com...-9fc6-2c86ae15abd6

BE11:59am

Oh noes!

11:59 am
